revision.text:
[[File:Tonghai Xian - Xiaohui Cun - P1360049.JPG|thumb|300px|Posters explaining the illegality of the theft of electric cables, outside of a mosque in [[Tonghai County]], [[Yunnan]].]]
'''Theft of electricity''' is the criminal practice of stealing [[electrical power]]. It is a crime and is punishable by fines and/or [[incarceration]]. It belongs to the [[Losses in electrical systems|non-technical losses]].
According to the annual ''Emerging Markets Smart Grid: Outlook 2015'' study by the Northeast Group, LLC, the world loses US$89.3 billion annually to electricity theft. The highest losses were in [[India]] ($16.2 billion), followed by [[Brazil]] ($10.5 billion) and [[Russia]] ($5.1 billion).<ref>http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/world-loses-893-billion-to-electricity-theft-annually-587-billion-in-emerging-markets-300006515.html</ref>
President of Northeast Group [[Ben Gardner]] stated : "India loses more money to theft than any other country in the world. The state of [[Maharashtra]]—which includes [[Mumbai]]—alone loses $2.8 billion per year, more than all but eight countries in the world. Nationally, total transmission and distribution losses approach 23% and some states' losses exceed 50%."<ref>http://tdworld.com/smart-grid/india-spend-216-billion-smart-grid-infrastructure-2025</ref>
== Types == There are various types of electrical power theft, including Tapping a line or bypassing the [[energy meter]]. According to a study {{cn|date=January 2016}}, 80% of worldwide theft occurs in private dwellings and 20% on commercial and industrial premises. The various types of electrical power theft include:
=== Direct hooking from line === What's known as "Cable Hooking" is the most used method. 80% of global power theft is by direct tapping from the line. The consumer taps into a power line from a point ahead of the [[energy meter]]. This [[energy]] consumption is unmeasured and procured with or without switches. {{citation needed|date=October 2018}}
=== Bypassing the energy meter === In this method, the input terminal and output terminal of the energy meter is short-circuited, preventing the energy from registration in the energy meter.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Power Theft|last=Sreenivasan|first=|publisher=PHI Learning[P]Ltd|year=2017|isbn=9788120352810|location=NewDelhi|pages=87-88}}</ref>
=== Injecting foreign element into the energy meter ===
Meters are manipulated via a remote by installing a circuit inside the meter so that the meter can be slowed down at any time. This kind of modification can evade external inspection attempts because the meter is always correct unless the remote is turned on.
=== Physical obstruction ===
This type of tampering is done to [[electromechanical]] meters with a rotating element. Foreign material is placed inside the meter to obstruct the free movement of the disc. A slower rotating disk signals less energy consumption.
=== ESD attack on electronic meter ===
This type of tampering is done on electronic meter to make it either latent damage or permanent damage. Detection can be done correctly in high end meters only.
== Detection ==
A number of approaches to detect electricity theft have been proposed. The predominant direction in research and development is employing [[artificial intelligence]], and in particular [[machine learning|machine learning methods]], to detect customers that steal electricity.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Glauner |first1=P. |display-authors=etal |year=2017 |title=The Challenge of Non-Technical Loss Detection using Artificial Intelligence: A Survey |url= |journal=International Journal of Computational Intelligence Systems |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=760-775 |doi=10.2991/ijcis.2017.10.1.51|arxiv=1606.00626 }}</ref>
== In popular culture ==
''[[Katiyabaaz]]'' (Powerless), a 2014 Indian [[documentary film]], dealt with issue of power theft in the city of [[Kanpur]], Uttar Pradesh.<ref name=toi>{{cite web | title = 'Katiyabaaz': A documentary maker challenges mainstream space | url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/Katiyabaaz-A-documentary-maker-challenges-mainstream-space/articleshow/40768405.cms |date= Aug 23, 2014| accessdate = 2014-08-30 | publisher = The Times of India}}</ref>
== History ==
On March 27, 1886 it was reported that electricity espionage was accomplished by unscrupulous persons tapping into Edison Electricity in New York. The Superintendent of the power station sent a power surge into the line to burn out or destroy foreign objects trespassing on the line. <ref>{{cite web | title = People Who Steal Edison's Electricity | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86075021/1886-03-27/ed-1/seq-2/print/image_681x648_from_493%2C4711_to_2380%2C6508/#Cite_Brian_Cohen |date= March 27, 1886| accessdate = 2016-07-09 | publisher = Daily Yellowstone journal}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links ==
* [http://punjabitribuneonline.com/2010/07/%E0%A8%AC%E0%A8%BF%E0%A8%9C%E0%A8%B2%E0%A9%80-%E0%A8%9A%E0%A9%8B%E0%A8%B0%E0%A9%80-%E0%A8%95%E0%A8%B0%E0%A8%A8-%E0%A8%A6%E0%A9%87-%E0%A8%A6%E0%A9%8B%E0%A8%B6-%E2%80%99%E0%A8%9A-%E0%A8%97%E0%A9%88/ Gas Link Company punished for kundi] * [http://www.tribuneindia.com/2002/20020104/haryana.htm#2 40% households in Haryana use kundi]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Theft of Electricity}}

revision.text:
'''Tub''' was a unit of capacity or of weight used in Britain and elsewhere.
==British unit for butter and cheese== British laws for the sale of goods defined a tub of [[butter]] as a receptacle of a size which could contain 84 pounds of butter.<ref name=robinson>{{cite book|last1=Robinson|first1=William|title=The Magistrate's Pocket-book, Or, An Epitome of the Duties and Practice of a Justice of the Peace,|date=1825|publisher=C. Hunter|page=50|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=jY8DAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA50#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=9 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=crabb>{{cite book|last1=Crabb|first1=George|title=A Digest and Index with Chronological Tables of All the Statutes: From Magna Charta to the End of this Last|date=1841|publisher=A. Maxwell & son|page=231|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Rk8DAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA231#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=9 April 2015}}</ref>
=== Definition ===
1 tub of butter or cheese = 84 pounds<ref name=robinson /><ref name=crabb />
=== Conversion ===
1 tub = 1.5 Firkin (1 Firkin = 56 lbs)<ref name=robinson /><ref name=crabb />
===Metric equivalent === 1 tub = {{convert|84|lb|kg|disp=out}}
==Other commodities== The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' has quotations illustrating other values of a "tub" as a unit:<ref name=oed>{{cite book|title=Oxford English Dictionary|url=http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/207129|accessdate=9 April 2015|chapter=Tub, n1, 1, d}}</ref> *[[Tea]] (1706): "about 60 pounds" *"Camphire" (1706): "from 56 to 86 pounds" *[[Vermilion]] (1706): "3 to 4 hundred weight" (i.e. 336-448 pounds) *[[Camphor]] (1858): "130 Dutch lbs"
In [[Newfoundland]], Canada, a tub of [[coal]] was defined as 100 pounds, while a tub of [[herring]]s was 16 Imperial gallons and a tub of [[salt]] was 18 Imperial gallons.<ref name=rowlett>{{cite web|last1=Rowlett|first1=Russ|title=How Many? A Dictionary of Units of Measurement|url=http://www.unc.edu/~rowlett/units/dictU.html|accessdate=9 April 2015}}</ref>
==References==
{{Reflist}}
